messageBody:
On 29.5.2007 Michael Everson wrote:

> Cyrillic shares very few letterforms with Greek.

Yet contemporary uncial Greek was a proper subset of Old
Cyrillic. The difference between modern minuscle Greek and
Cyrillic can after all be argued to be a style difference
analogous to the case of Greek and Coptic.

This said I think the difference of style argument is
convincing, and I agree such a difference is lacking in the
QS/Shavian case.

> Sorry. A case needs to be made to disunify Shavian and QS.
> So far I haven't seen anything, and reflecting about it
> and studying so far I don't think it's a credible
> approach.

The point is not one of graphic design and similarity of
glyphs, but a political one.

People *think of* them and *want* them as two different
alphabets, which ought to weigh in. Similarly the difference
between Hiragana and Katakana could have been handled as
analogous to the Roman/Italic distinction in Latin (not that
that would have been a Good Thing), but the Japanese didn't
want it that way.

Kannada and Telugu come to mind as an analogous case, being
arguably as much or even more graphically similar than QS
and Shavian, sharing a common origin and lots of similar
shapes with similar values. I'll admit there may
be style differences that might persist in even the most
progressive typographic expression, but the difference
between straight and curved matras seem to me of more
political than practical significance, and the QS/Shavian
distinction is likewise more political than practical.

We are talking about some forty code points here. Why lump
them *against the will of the users* when every obscure Han
character variants used only in ten people's given name gets
its point?

/BP
